<font face="Fredoka One">Use space bar to advance</font>
<font face="Fredoka One, cursive" color="#7a7575">Current direction</font>
<font face="Fredoka One">(if this is a video, ignore the space bar)</font>
This presentation is not about how electrons flow...

Conventional
Flow

Electron
Flow

This presentation is about understanding current 
directions in a circuit while analyzing it.

Which direction
should we pick ?

Before answering that question,
let's review a couple of rules...

The sum of currents entering a node...
is equal to the sum of currents leaving the node.

Kirchhoff's Current Law
 (KCL)
Passive Sign Convention

Current entering
the positive terminal...

Current entering
the negative terminal...

... has a positive 
voltage drop.

... has a negative 
voltage drop.
KCL Example...
Passive Sign Example...

Let's cover an example where all
these concepts are connected together...
(Circuit Link)

Notice there are no signs or currents
assigned in this circuit...
Pick any direction of current that you want...
Don't overthink...
There are a lot of possible combinations...
But they will all give the same result.
Let's get back to this configuration.
Assign + and - around the resistors...
Once again, pick whatever direction you want.
<font face="Fredoka One" color="#f52222">+</font>
<font face="Fredoka One" color="#f52222">+</font>
<font face="Fredoka One" color="#f52222">+</font>
<font face="Fredoka One" color="#f52222">-</font>
<font face="Fredoka One" color="#f52222">-</font>
<font face="Fredoka One" color="#f52222">-</font>
Don't overthink...

From now on, apply KCL and passive sign
to get the equations out of the circuit.

Let's do another example.

Substituting everything into the KCL equation...
You get the same result.
Notice on how both calculations give the same voltage for VA
But different currents for V2
Which current is correct?
A
A

Conventional
Flow

Electron
Flow

Both are valid, because it depends
on which direction of current you are considering
during your calculations...

Conventional
Flow

The passive sign convention defined earlier, assumes
conventional flow of current...
With that in mind:
has the correct sign.

If you are missing information in the circuit, there is no
way to know current directions...
• You need to pick some current directions
• Assign voltages to the resistors
• Get the values

• And understand if your initial directions
    are correct

• On the other end, voltages will always be
    correct

With time you will be able to predict
some current directions just by looking at the circuit...
But it is totally fine if you struggle with that...

Apply the concepts from this presentation and
you will be fine.
Thank you!
